 \[[ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82_%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82_%D0%A2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE "ru:Десант в порт Торо")<br>        \]<br>    *   [Otomari](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_assault_on_Otomari&action=edit&redlink=1 "Soviet assault on Otomari (page does not exist)")<br>        <br>*   [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Invasion_of_the_Kuril_Islands "Invasion of the Kuril Islands")<br>    *   [Shumshu](/wiki/Battle_of_Shumshu "Battle of Shumshu")<br>        <br>*   [Hokkaido (cancelled)](/wiki/Proposed_Soviet_invasion_of_Hokkaido "Proposed Soviet invasion of Hokkaido") |     |

The **Soviet invasion of Manchuria**, formally known as the **Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation**[\[15\]](#cite_note-22)
 or simply the **Manchurian Operation** (Маньчжурская операция) and sometimes **Operation August Storm**,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 began on 9 August 1945 with the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 invasion of the [Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
's [puppet state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state")
 of [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
, which was situated in Japanese-occupied [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")
. Soviet paratroopers destroyed the Kwantung Army from behind its own lines, while Japanese anti-tank shells bounced off the sides of Soviet tanks.[\[39\]](#cite_note-47)
 The Japanese forces in Manchuria retreated in fear.[\[40\]](#cite_note-48)

Japanese troops and able-bodied Japanese men in Manchuria were taken prisoner by the Russians and transported to labor camps in Siberia, where many Japanese men would die.[\[41\]](#cite_note-49)
 From the Russians' perspective, this was seen as revenge for Russia's defeat in the [Russo-Japanese War](/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War "Russo-Japanese War")
 of 1905.[\[42\]](#cite_note-50)
 The stories of how poorly the Soviets treated the Japanese were brought to [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing")
 by Japanese evacuees of Manchuria, creating panic among the Japanese population; however, the Russians honored their agreement with Chiang Kai-shek by not entering China proper.[\[43\]](#cite_note-51)

Japanese communication infrastructure was poor, and the Japanese lost communication with forward units very early on. reports indicate that the Soviet troops that occupied Manchuria (about 700,000) also looted and terrorized the local people of Mukden and were not discouraged by Soviet authorities from "three days of rape and pillage." In Harbin, Soviet forces ignored protests from [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China "Communist Party of China")
 leaders on the mass rape and looting.[\[62\]](#cite_note-FCJones-70)
[\[63\]](#cite_note-CSM-71)
[\[64\]](#cite_note-72)
[\[65\]](#cite_note-73)
[\[66\]](#cite_note-74)
[\[67\]](#cite_note-75)
 There were several incidents in which Chinese police forces in Manchuria arrested or even killed Soviet troops for committing various crimes, leading to some conflicts between the Soviet and Chinese authorities in Manchuria.[\[68\]](#cite_note-76)

During the [Soviet occupation of North Korea](/wiki/Soviet_Civil_Administration "Soviet Civil Administration")
, it was reported that Soviet soldiers committed rape against both [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_people "Japanese people")
 and [Korean](/wiki/Koreans "Koreans")
 women alike in the northern half of the Korean peninsula.[\[69\]](#cite_note-77)
[\[70\]](#cite_note-78)
 Soviet soldiers also looted the property of both Japanese and Koreans living in northern Korea.[\[71\]](#cite_note-:0-79)
 The Soviets laid claim to Japanese enterprises in Manchuria and northern Korea and took valuable materials and industrial equipment.[\[62\]](#cite_note-FCJones-70)
[\[71\]](#cite_note-:0-79)

Konstantin Asmolov of the Center for Korean Research of the [Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences "Russian Academy of Sciences")
 dismisses Western accounts of Soviet violence against civilians in the Far East as exaggeration and rumor and contends that accusations of mass crimes by the Red Army inappropriately extrapolate isolated incidents regarding the nearly 2,000,000 Soviet troops in the Far East into mass crimes. **[^](#cite_ref-CSM_71-0)
    ** _Christian Science Monitor_, 12 October 1945, Japanese armies were guilty of appalling excesses, both in China and elsewhere, and had the Russians dealt harshly with only Japanese nationals in Manchuria this would have appeared as just retribution. The Japanese did not have any concrete evidence as to when or where any invasion would occur.[\[17\]](#cite_note-Drea-24)
 They had estimated that an attack was not likely before the spring of 1946, but the _[Stavka](/wiki/Stavka "Stavka")
_ had in fact been planning for a mid-August offensive, successfully [concealing the buildup](/wiki/Russian_military_deception "Russian military deception")
 of a force of 90 divisions. This attack involved the [1st Red Banner Army](/wiki/Soviet_First_Army "Soviet First Army")
, the [5th Army](/wiki/5th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "5th Army (Soviet Union)")
 and the [10th Mechanized Corps](/wiki/10th_Mechanized_Corps "10th Mechanized Corps")
 striking towards [Mudanjiang](/wiki/Mudanjiang "Mudanjiang")
 (or Mutanchiang).[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Once that city was captured, this force was to advance towards the cities of [Jilin](/wiki/Jilin "Jilin")
 (or Kirin), Changchun and Harbin.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Its final objective was to link up with the forces of the Transbaikal Front at Changchun and Jilin thus closing the double envelopment movement.

As a secondary objective, the 1st Far Eastern Front was to prevent Japanese forces from escaping to [Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea")
, and then invade the [Korean Peninsula](/wiki/Korean_Peninsula "Korean Peninsula")
 up to the [38th parallel](/wiki/38th_parallel_north#Korea "38th parallel north")
,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 establishing in the process what later became [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea")
. This secondary objective was to be carried out by the [25th Army](/wiki/25th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "25th Army (Soviet Union)")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Meanwhile, the [35th Army](/wiki/35th_Army_(Russia) "35th Army (Russia)")
 was tasked with capturing the cities of [Boli](/wiki/Boli_County "Boli County")
 (or Poli), [Linkou](/w/index.php?title=Linkou,_Heilongjiang&action=edit&redlink=1 "Linkou, Heilongjiang (page does not exist)")
 and [Mishan](/wiki/Mishan "Mishan")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

#### 2nd Far Eastern Front

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 2nd Far Eastern Front")\
\]

The 2nd Far Eastern Front, under General [Maksim Purkayev](/wiki/Maksim_Purkayev "Maksim Purkayev")
, included:[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

*   [2nd Red Banner Army](/wiki/Soviet_Second_Army "Soviet Second Army")
    
*   [15th Army](/wiki/15th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "15th Army (Soviet Union)")
    
*   [16th Army](/wiki/16th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "16th Army (Soviet Union)")
     (whose 56th Rifle Corps was its only formation to see combat, on [South Sakhalin](/wiki/South_Sakhalin "South Sakhalin")
    )
*   [5th Separate Rifle Corps](/wiki/5th_Separate_Rifle_Corps "5th Separate Rifle Corps")
    
*   [Chuguevsk Operational Group](/w/index.php?title=Chuguevsk_Operational_Group&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chuguevsk Operational Group (page does not exist)")
    
*   [Amur Military Flotilla](/wiki/Amur_Military_Flotilla "Amur Military Flotilla")
    
*   [10th Air Army](/wiki/10th_Air_Army "10th Air Army")
    

The 2nd Far Eastern Front was deployed in a supporting attack role.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Its objectives were the cities of Harbin and Qiqihar,[\[2\]](#cite_note-Battlefield_Series-2)
 and to prevent an orderly withdrawal to the south by the Japanese forces.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 The front also included the [88th Separate Rifle Brigade](/wiki/88th_Separate_Rifle_Brigade "88th Separate Rifle Brigade")
, composed of Chinese and Korean guerrillas of the [Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army](/wiki/Northeast_Anti-Japanese_United_Army "Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army")
 who had retreated into the USSR in the beginning of the 1940s. The Kwantung Army commanders were engaged in a planning exercise at the time of the invasion, and were away from their forces for the first eighteen hours of conflict.

The Russians treated the Japanese with the utmost cruelty after their deadly attack on Japan's Kwantung Army in Manchuria just days before Japan's surrender.[\[38\]](#cite_note-46)
 Japanese forces were overwhelmed by Soviet attacks."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army. The invasion resulted in the collapse of Japanese puppet states, the partition of the Korean Peninsula, and the return of most of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to the Nationalist government of China. The search result also mentions the involvement of Mongolia in the invasion. The Japanese forces were taken prisoner and transported to labor camps in Siberia. The result also mentions looting and violence against civilians by Soviet troops.

By: HISTORY.com Editors

1945

Soviets declare war on Japan, invade Manchuria the next day
===========================================================

[HISTORY.com Editors](/authors/history)

Published: August 06, 2010

Last Updated: May 27, 2025

Print

Share

On August 8, 1945, the [Soviet Union](/topics/history-of-the-soviet-union)
 officially [declares war on Japan](https://blog.nationalarchives.gov.uk/soviet-japan-and-the-termination-of-the-second-world-war/#:~:text=However%2C%20on%208,Japan%20to%20surrender.)
, pouring more than 1 million Soviet soldiers the following day into [Japanese-occupied Manchuria](https://blog.nationalarchives.gov.uk/soviet-japan-and-the-termination-of-the-second-world-war/#:~:text=The%20Soviets%20launched%20their%20invasion%20simultaneously%20on%20three%20fronts%20in%20the%20east%2C%20west%20and%20north%20of%20Manchuria%2C%20the%20day%20after%20the%20declaration%20of%20war.)
, northeastern China, to take on the 700,000-strong Japanese army.

The [dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima](https://www.history.com/topics/world-war-ii/bombing-of-hiroshima-and-nagasaki)
 by the Americans did not have the effect intended: unconditional surrender by Japan. But if you see something that doesn't look right, [click here](mailto:support@history.zendesk.com?subject=Fact%20Check%20-%20Soviets%20declare%20war%20on%20Japan%2C%20invade%20Manchuria%20the%20next%20day)
 to contact us! HISTORY reviews and updates its content regularly to ensure it is complete and accurate.

History Every Day




-----------------------

Sign Up for "This Day in History"
---------------------------------

Uncover fascinating moments from the past every day! Half of the Japanese inner Cabinet, called the Supreme War Direction Council, refused to surrender unless guarantees about Japan’s future were given by the Allies, especially regarding the position of the emperor, [Hirohito](/topics/world-war-ii/hirohito)
. The only Japanese civilians who even knew what happened at Hiroshima were either dead or suffering terribly.

Japan had not been too worried about the Soviet Union, so busy with the Germans on the Eastern front. The Japanese army went so far as to believe that they would not have to engage a Soviet attack until spring 1946. But the Soviets surprised them one day after the declaration of war with their invasion of Manchuria, an assault so strong (of the 850 Japanese soldiers engaged at Pingyanchen, 650 were killed or wounded within the first two days of fighting) that Emperor Hirohito began to plead with his War Council to reconsider surrender. The match-up drew 12,000 people at a \[…\]\
\
2:04m read read](/this-day-in-history/august-8/lights-go-on-at-wrigley)

The explicit reason was to swiftly end the war with Japan."

Top Questions

### 

What caused the Russo-Japanese War?

The war developed from [Russia](https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia)
’s and [Japan](https://www.britannica.com/place/Japan)
’s rivalry for dominance in [Korea](https://www.britannica.com/place/Korea)
 and [Manchuria](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria)
. The engagement took place on May 27–29, 1905, with Japan inflicting a crushing defeat on the Russian navy.(more)

**Russo-Japanese War**, (1904–05), military conflict in which a victorious [Japan](https://www.britannica.com/place/Japan)
 forced [Russia](https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia)
 to abandon its expansionist policy in [East Asia](https://www.britannica.com/place/East-Asia)
, thereby becoming the first Asian power in modern times to defeat a European power.

Origins of the Russo-Japanese War
---------------------------------

[![Russian Empire](https://cdn.britannica.com/50/3850-050-460382BE/Russian-expansion-Asia.jpg?w=300)](https://cdn.britannica.com/50/3850-050-460382BE/Russian-expansion-Asia.jpg)

Russian Empire <image:2464>
Map of Russian expansion in Asia, 1533–1894.(more)

By the early 17th century, Russia had established its authority over all of [Siberia](https://www.britannica.com/place/Siberia)
, but its attempts to move southward were consistently blocked by [China](https://www.britannica.com/place/China)
. Japan, with its modernized army and navy, at once won a series of striking victories against the Chinese, who, in the [Treaty of Shimonoseki](https://www.britannica.com/event/Treaty-of-Shimonoseki)
 (April 17, 1895), ceded to Japan the [Kwantung (Liaodong) Peninsula](https://www.britannica.com/place/Liaodong-Peninsula)
, on which Port Arthur (now [Dalian](https://www.britannica.com/place/Dalian)
) stands, together with Formosa ([Taiwan](https://www.britannica.com/place/Taiwan)
) and the [Pescadores (P’eng-hu) Islands](https://www.britannica.com/place/Peng-hu-Islands)
, and agreed to pay a heavy indemnity.

This display of Japanese power and its decisive victory over China threatened to close the door on Russia in East Asia, and it made conflict between Russia and Japan inevitable. In 1896 Russia concluded an alliance with China against Japan, guaranteeing the [integrity](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integrity)
 of Chinese territory. Russia thus entered into the occupation of the Kwantung Peninsula, from which only three years earlier it had excluded Japan.

[![What happened during the Boxer Rebellion in China?](https://cdn.britannica.com/15/180115-138-76A93B98/Video-overview-Boxer-Rebellion.jpg?w=800&h=450&c=crop)](/video/Video-overview-Boxer-Rebellion/-203056)

What happened during the Boxer Rebellion in China?Video overview of the Boxer Rebellion.(more)

[See all videos for this article](/event/Russo-Japanese-War/images-videos)

The seizure of Chinese territory by Germany and Russia was followed by British demands for [Weihai](https://www.britannica.com/place/Weihai)
 and French claims on Kwangchow (now [Guangzhou](https://www.britannica.com/place/Guangzhou)
). Realizing that Japan had gained preponderance in East Asia, in the summer of 1903 he recommended that Russia should abandon its projects in Manchuria and restore Port Arthur to China in return for [concessions](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/concessions)
 in the Vladivostok region. However, the lessons of Port Arthur would go largely unheeded by European commanders, who would replicate the same sanguinary tactics on the [Western Front](https://www.britannica.com/event/Western-Front-World-War-I)
 during [World War I](https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-I)
.

[![Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/07/146507-050-F4C5DF77/Meeting-Russian-generals-terms-Japanese-surrender-Russo-Japanese.jpg?w=300)\
\
1 of 3](https://cdn.britannica.com/07/146507-050-F4C5DF77/Meeting-Russian-generals-terms-Japanese-surrender-Russo-Japanese.jpg)

[Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/07/146507-050-F4C5DF77/Meeting-Russian-generals-terms-Japanese-surrender-Russo-Japanese.jpg)
Meeting between Anatoly Stessel of Russia and Nogi Maresuke of Japan, opposing generals in the Russo-Japanese War, January 27, 1905.(more)

[![Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/06/146506-050-1B0D0997/Anatoly-Stessel-Russia-toast-generals-Japan-Nogi-Jan-27-1905.jpg?w=300)\
\
2 of 3](https://cdn.britannica.com/06/146506-050-1B0D0997/Anatoly-Stessel-Russia-toast-generals-Japan-Nogi-Jan-27-1905.jpg)

[Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/06/146506-050-1B0D0997/Anatoly-Stessel-Russia-toast-generals-Japan-Nogi-Jan-27-1905.jpg)
Anatoly Stessel (left) of Russia and Nogi Maresuke of Japan, opposing generals in the Russo-Japanese War, sharing a toast after arranging the terms of Russia's surrender of Port Arthur (now Lüshun, China), January 27, 1905.(more)

[![Battleships at Port Arthur](https://cdn.britannica.com/14/146514-050-E3227B03/battleships-Russian-Port-Arthur-Russo-Japanese-War-1904.jpg?w=300)\
\
3 of 3](https://cdn.britannica.com/14/146514-050-E3227B03/battleships-Russian-Port-Arthur-Russo-Japanese-War-1904.jpg)

[Battleships at Port Arthur](https://cdn.britannica.com/14/146514-050-E3227B03/battleships-Russian-Port-Arthur-Russo-Japanese-War-1904.jpg)
Stranded Russian battleships at Port Arthur days before its fall during the Russo-Japanese War, 1904.(more)

Among the Russian commanders at Port Arthur there was serious disagreement. Russia agreed to evacuate southern Manchuria, which was restored to China, and Japan’s control of Korea was recognized. Russia nevertheless remained an Asian power, possessing as it did the railways across Siberia and northern Manchuria to Vladivostok and being closely allied with China.

Japan, for its part, formalized its hold on Korea by forcing [Kojong](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Gojong)
, the final monarch of the Chosŏn (Yi) [dynasty](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynasty)
, to [abdicate](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/abdicate)
 in 1907."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Britannica article discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), a military conflict in which Japan defeated Russia. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. The article mentions that Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia. <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The article also mentions the Treaty of Shimonoseki, in which Japan gained control of the Kwantung Peninsula.

_________________________

* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria): 
Content: The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army. The invasion resulted in the collapse of Japanese puppet states, the partition of the Korean Peninsula, and the return of most of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to the Nationalist government of China. The search result also mentions the involvement of Mongolia in the invasion. The Japanese forces were taken prisoner and transported to labor camps in Siberia. The result also mentions looting and violence against civilians by Soviet troops.


From [Source](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/august-8/soviets-declare-war-on-japan-invade-manchuria): 
Content: History.com published an article on August 6, 2010, and last updated on May 27, 2025, by HISTORY.com Editors, discussing the Soviet Union's declaration of war on Japan on August 8, 1945, and the subsequent invasion of Manchuria the following day. <image:i>.


From [Source](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War): 
Content: The Britannica article discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), a military conflict in which Japan defeated Russia. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. The article mentions that Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia. <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The article also mentions the Treaty of Shimonoseki, in which Japan gained control of the Kwantung Peninsula.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army, as detailed in an article from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria). This invasion led to the collapse of Japanese puppet states and the return of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to China. History.com published an article on August 6, 2010, and last updated on May 27, 2025, discussing the Soviet Union's declaration of war on Japan on August 8, 1945, and the subsequent invasion of Manchuria the following day, as stated in [History.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/august-8/soviets-declare-war-on-japan-invade-manchuria) <image:i>.

The Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), in which Japan defeated Russia, is discussed in an article from [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War) <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia.

_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invade Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army, as detailed in an article from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria). This invasion led to the collapse of Japanese puppet states and the return of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to China. History.com published an article on August 6, 2010, and last updated on May 27, 2025, discussing the Soviet Union's declaration of war on Japan on August 8, 1945, and the subsequent invasion of Manchuria the following day, as stated in [History.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/august-8/soviets-declare-war-on-japan-invade-manchuria) <image:i>.

The Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), in which Japan defeated Russia, is discussed in an article from [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War) <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The provided evidence does not support the claim that China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation. The search results detail historical conflicts between Russia and Japan, including the Russo-Japanese War and the Soviet invasion of Manchuria. However, these historical events do not indicate current plans for invasion.

The evidence highlights past conflicts and territorial disputes, but it does not provide any information about current military strategies or intentions of China or Japan towards Russia.

To verify the claim, information about current geopolitical relations, military strategies, and any official statements from China and Japan regarding Russia would be needed.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invade Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army, as detailed in an article from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria). This invasion led to the collapse of Japanese puppet states and the return of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to China. History.com published an article on August 6, 2010, and last updated on May 27, 2025, discussing the Soviet Union's declaration of war on Japan on August 8, 1945, and the subsequent invasion of Manchuria the following day, as stated in [History.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/august-8/soviets-declare-war-on-japan-invade-manchuria) <image:i>.

The Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), in which Japan defeated Russia, is discussed in an article from [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War) <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia.


## Elaboration
The provided evidence does not support the claim that China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation. The search results detail historical conflicts between Russia and Japan, including the Russo-Japanese War and the Soviet invasion of Manchuria. However, these historical events do not indicate current plans for invasion.

The evidence highlights past conflicts and territorial disputes, but it does not provide any information about current military strategies or intentions of China or Japan towards Russia.

To verify the claim, information about current geopolitical relations, military strategies, and any official statements from China and Japan regarding Russia would be needed.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results describe historical conflicts between Russia, China, and Japan, but they do not provide any evidence to support the claim that China and Japan are currently planning to invade Russia. The evidence focuses on past wars and territorial disputes, not on present-day military strategies or intentions.

`false`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invade Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Soviet Union invaded Manchuria in August 1945, defeating the Japanese Kwantung Army, as detailed in an article from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria). This invasion led to the collapse of Japanese puppet states and the return of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia to China. History.com published an article on August 6, 2010, and last updated on May 27, 2025, discussing the Soviet Union's declaration of war on Japan on August 8, 1945, and the subsequent invasion of Manchuria the following day, as stated in [History.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/august-8/soviets-declare-war-on-japan-invade-manchuria) <image:i>.

The Russo-Japanese War (1904–05), in which Japan defeated Russia, is discussed in an article from [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War) <image:2464>, <image:2459>. The war was caused by the rivalry between Russia and Japan for dominance in Korea and Manchuria. Japan forced Russia to abandon its expansionist policy in East Asia.


## Elaboration
The provided evidence does not support the claim that China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation. The search results detail historical conflicts between Russia and Japan, including the Russo-Japanese War and the Soviet invasion of Manchuria. However, these historical events do not indicate current plans for invasion.

The evidence highlights past conflicts and territorial disputes, but it does not provide any information about current military strategies or intentions of China or Japan towards Russia.

To verify the claim, information about current geopolitical relations, military strategies, and any official statements from China and Japan regarding Russia would be needed.


## Final Judgement
The search results describe historical conflicts between Russia, China, and Japan, but they do not provide any evidence to support the claim that China and Japan are currently planning to invade Russia. The evidence focuses on past wars and territorial disputes, not on present-day military strategies or intentions.

`false`


## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results reveal historical conflicts between Russia, Japan, and China, such as the [Russo-Japanese War](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War) and the Soviet invasion of Manchuria, but they do not provide any evidence to support the claim that China and Japan are currently planning to invade Russia.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim

```

```

```

```

```

* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

[!Russia Notes US Hypocrisy in California Fire Case <image:4830>](/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)

### TEHRAN (Tasnim) - Russian Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on reports that hundreds of prisoners have been mobilized to extinguish fires in the US state of California, pointing to the hypocrisy of the US.

[\- Other Media news -](/en/service/1200/other-media)

Earlier, The Washington Post, citing the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, reported that the state authorities had sent 395 prisoners to fight forest fires. The diplomat noted that in 2023, Washington restricted imports of products from several Chinese companies in an attempt to exclude goods allegedly produced with the help of Uygur forced labor from the US supply chain.

"This raises a logical question: will Congress draft a bill imposing sanctions on California authorities, private companies, and ordinary Americans for using prison labor to put out fires?" she wondered. "We are so sick of this hypocrisy!" Zakharova added.

Wildfires began to spread across Los Angeles County on January 7."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Tasnim News Agency, published on January 12, 2025, discusses Russia's comments on the California wildfires. The article mentions that Russia's Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on reports that prisoners were mobilized to extinguish fires in California. <image:4830>. The article also mentions that wildfires began to spread across Los Angeles County on January 7. <image:4831>.

Gift Article

Did Russia offer sanctuary to California residents who lost their homes in the Los Angeles fires? A viral X [post](https://x.com/jacksonhinklle/status/1879042008465183185)
 by Jackson Hinkle—a [regular purveyor](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/11/business/media/jackson-hinkle-israel-gaza-misinformation.html)
 of Russia-related misinformation—claims so.

“BREAKING: RUSSIA has offered shelter & sanctuary to Californians whose livelihoods were DESTROYED in the LA wildfires,” reads the post, which had more than 500,000 views on X as of January 15. 

[Fact Check](https://thedispatch.com/category/fact-check/)

Assessing Claims That Russia Offered Sanctuary to California Fire Victims
=========================================================================

One Russian governor did make an offer, but there are some caveats.

! A single Russian governor said that he would welcome California fire victims to the region of occupied Ukraine he oversees, but only if they don’t support the government in Kyiv.

On Monday, Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, [told](https://tass.ru/obschestvo/22867057)
 _TASS_—a Russian state-controlled media outlet—that the region would accept any Americans who lost their homes in this month’s California fires. “Despite the ongoing, blatantly anti-Russian policy of the United States, we fully understand that natural disasters don’t care who you are or what you do,” Saldo said, [according to](https://www.rt.com/russia/610836-california-fires-sanctuary-kherson/)
 Russia Today, a Russian state-controlled network that translated the statement into English. Therefore, our region is ready to welcome any American citizen who has lost their home and livelihood.”

That offer comes with a caveat, applying only to Californians who haven’t supported Ukraine since Russia invaded its borders in February 2022. Sutton")
, and [Cole Murphy](https://thedispatch.com/author/cole-murphy/ "Posts by Cole Murphy")

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Dispatch published an article on January 15, 2025, discussing claims that Russia offered sanctuary to California fire victims. The article states that Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, offered to accept Americans who lost their homes in the California fires, but only those who haven't supported Ukraine since February 2022. <image:4838>

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

### [LA fires are still raging, but forecasters expect calmer winds in the coming days](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/15/nx-s1-5260939/fires-los-angeles-palisades-eaton-wildfires-winds)

"It is the latest in a long string of assertions by Russian officials, media, and the pro-Kremlin online ecosystem that Ukrainian officials are corrupt and use foreign aid money to enrich themselves." Léa Ronzaud, a senior investigator at research firm Graphika, told NPR in an email.

**Russia tries to use California fires to discredit Ukraine** **Pro-Kremlin social media accounts and outlets have been spreading a baseless narrative that mansions belonging to Ukrainian officials burned down in Los Angeles.**

How Russia used the Los Angeles fires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda
=======================================================================

  

January 16, 202512:47 PM ET

Heard on [All Things Considered](https://www.npr.org/programs/all-things-considered/2025/01/16/all-things-considered-for-january-16-2025)

By 

[Huo Jingnan](https://www.npr.org/people/726257042/huo-jingnan)

The story that initially circulated was debunked by professional fact checkers from [Greece](https://www.factchecker.gr/2025/01/12/russian-propaganda-8-mansions-of-high-ranking-ukrainian-military-officials-did-not-burn-down-in-los-angeles/)
 and the [United States](https://www.snopes.com/news/2025/01/13/wildfires-ukraine-mansions/)
.

Mario Tama/Getty Images

Pro-Kremlin social media accounts and outlets have been spreading a [baseless narrative](https://www.snopes.com/news/2025/01/13/wildfires-ukraine-mansions/)
 that mansions belonging to Ukrainian military officers burned down [in the Los Angeles wildfires](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/15/nx-s1-5260939/fires-los-angeles-palisades-eaton-wildfires-winds)
. influencers to create viral videos](https://www.npr.org/2024/09/05/nx-s1-5100829/russia-election-influencers-youtube)

Other Russian Telegram channels are also spreading false or unverified narratives about the southern California fires and the government's response, as well as amplifying critiques from Americans including the president-elect's son, Donald Trump, Jr., Andy Carvin of the Atlantic Council's DFRLab told NPR in an email. The Russian news site [Pravda](https://web.archive.org/web/20250115205032/https://news-pravda.com/world/2025/01/08/963104.html)
, which has been associated with prior Russian information operations, then translates and distributes the Telegram posts.

"Over the last week, Pravda has published at least 350 stories of this type \[based on Telegram messages about the fires\], based on our initial content analysis of the site," Carvin said.

The article also noted that wildfires began spreading across Los Angeles County on January 7. ([https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)) <image:4830>, <image:4831>

([https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/](https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/)) <image:4838> NPR reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia used the Los Angeles wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda. DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires from January 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Russia California wildfires assistance 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Tasnim News Agency reported on January 12, 2025, that Russia's Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on the California wildfires, mentioning reports of prisoners being mobilized to extinguish the fires. The article also noted that wildfires began spreading across Los Angeles County on January 7. ([https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)) <image:4830>, <image:4831>

The Dispatch reported on January 15, 2025, that Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, offered sanctuary to California fire victims who had not supported Ukraine since February 2022. ([https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/](https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/)) <image:4838> NPR reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia used the Los Angeles wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda. ([https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine)) <image:4849>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence indicates that Russia commented on the California wildfires and that Vladimir Saldo offered sanctuary to fire victims. However, the evidence does not explicitly state that Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires.

The evidence suggests that Russia's involvement was more related to propaganda and offering sanctuary rather than direct assistance in extinguishing the fires.

To verify the claim, information is missing about whether Russia offered any form of assistance, such as personnel, equipment, or financial aid, to combat the wildfires.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires from January 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Russia California wildfires assistance 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Tasnim News Agency reported on January 12, 2025, that Russia's Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on the California wildfires, mentioning reports of prisoners being mobilized to extinguish the fires. The article also noted that wildfires began spreading across Los Angeles County on January 7. ([https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)) <image:4830>, <image:4831>

The Dispatch reported on January 15, 2025, that Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, offered sanctuary to California fire victims who had not supported Ukraine since February 2022. ([https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/](https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/)) <image:4838> NPR reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia used the Los Angeles wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda. ([https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine)) <image:4849>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Russia commented on the California wildfires and that Vladimir Saldo offered sanctuary to fire victims. However, the evidence does not explicitly state that Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires.

The evidence suggests that Russia's involvement was more related to propaganda and offering sanctuary rather than direct assistance in extinguishing the fires.

To verify the claim, information is missing about whether Russia offered any form of assistance, such as personnel, equipment, or financial aid, to combat the wildfires.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results show that Russia commented on the California wildfires and offered sanctuary to fire victims, but there is no evidence of Russia offering assistance to fight the fires.

Since the evidence does not confirm that Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires, the claim cannot be verified. `not enough information`

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: geolocate()

```

```

```

Breaking News

[Europe](/z/611)

Russia exploits wildfires in Los Angeles to push anti-US, anti-Ukraine propaganda
=================================================================================

January 16, 2025 8:15 AM

*   By [Leonid Martynyuk](/author/leonid-martynyuk/oymt_ "Leonid Martynyuk")
    

* * *

!Fire crews battle the Kenneth Fire in the West Hills section of Los Angeles, California, Jan. 9, 2025.

 [](https://www.voanews.com)

Russia exploits wildfires in Los Angeles to push anti-US, anti-Ukraine propaganda

#### Maria Zakharova

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman

U.S. uses forced labor by involving inmates in fighting Los Angeles fires, while sanctioning China for using forced labor in Xinjiang.

[Source: RIA Novosti, January 12, 2025](https://ria.ru/20250112/zaharova-1993301092.html "Source: RIA Novosti, January 12, 2025")

False

Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova accused the United States of “obscurantist hypocrisy” for allowing inmates to fight Los Angeles wildfires. has been condemning for years.

"Hundreds of prisoners have been recruited to fight wildfires in southern California … In recent years, U.S. officials have repeatedly criticized China for using forced labor, especially in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region … \[W\]ill Congress impose sanctions on the California government, private companies, and ordinary Americans for using prison labor to fight fires."

The claim is false.

[In California, inmates voluntarily join firefighting crews](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/10/nx-s1-5254122/inmate-firefighters-california-wildfires)
 if they meet the program’s qualifications, which consider physical fitness and behavioral records. government is impoverishing its own citizens.

Speaking at a January 14 press conference on the results of Russian diplomacy in 2024, Lavrov said, that Americans “burned almost all of California,” and the damage is estimated $250 billion, which is “comparable” to what the U.S. pledged to [Ukraine](https://www.state.gov/bureau-of-political-military-affairs/releases/2025/01/u-s-security-cooperation-with-ukraine)
 about $66.2 billion in [security assistance](https://media.defense.gov/2025/Jan/09/2003626079/-1/-1/1/KEY-ACHIEVEMENTS-AND-FACTS-US-SECURITY-ASSISTANCE-TO-UKRAINE.PDF)
 between 2014, when Russia annexed Crimea, and February 2022 when Moscow launched a war, and about $66.5 billion since.

Lavrov’s claim that by aiding Ukraine the U.S. society, in part due to the [Russian propaganda influence](https://www.npr.org/2024/09/07/nx-s1-5101895/doj-says-russia-paid-right-wing-influencers-to-spread-russian-propaganda)
.

Experts, however, argue that opposite to draining American economy, the large portion of the Ukraine aid is being reinvested domestically, [boosting defense manufacturing industry and sustaining jobs](https://www.wilsoncenter.org/blog-post/us-aid-ukraine-helps-american-economy-and-boosts-us-jobs)
.

Russian propaganda exploited the Ukrainian angle in the Los Angeles fires trying to spread false accusations against Ukraine’s military command of misappropriating the Western aid.

Russia’s newly emerged group of social media influencers nicknamed “milbloggers” as most members are either Russian combatants or pro-war reporters from the battle lines in Ukraine, played key role in creating and spreading such false claims.

Russian Telegram channel Voennyj obozrevatel' (Military Observer) alleged on January 11, that eight mansions worth a total of $90 million owned by high-ranking Ukrainian military officials, were destroyed in the Los Angeles wildfires.

“According to Ukrainian sources, 8 mansions owned by high-ranking Ukrainian military personnel were burned during large-scale wildfires in Los Angeles. The total value of these properties amounts to $90 million and was allegedly purchased with funds provided by the West as part of economic aid to Kyiv after the war began.”

Russian state-controlled news sites and media outlets, including Gazeta.ru, Lenta.ru, EADaily, News.ru, Komsomolskaya Pravda, Tsargrad, and Rossiyskaya Gazeta used the post in their news coverage.

[Multiple fact-checking outlets](https://www.factchecker.gr/2025/01/12/russian-propaganda-8-mansions-of-high-ranking-ukrainian-military-officials-did-not-burn-down-in-los-angeles/)
 and even some Russian news media debunked the post as lacking merit and unsubstantiated.

Yet the claim about the luxury villas of Ukrainian generals allegedly burning down in Los Angeles spread on X the following days, receiving millions of views and thousands of reposts.

In another disinformation plot, on January 13-14, Russian state-owned news sites sought to undermine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's decision to send Ukrainian firefighters to Los Angeles to help put out the wildfires.

State-owned RIA Novosti, RT, and others used an X post by “Ukrainian journalist” Diana Panchenko, who wrote responding to Zeleskyy’s announcement: "I am glad that hundreds of men will have the opportunity to leave Ukraine these days."

Russian news outlets generalized the post, speculating it signaled that Ukrainian journalists oppose Ukraine's fight for independence and the Ukrainian men are desperate to leave the country.

In fact, Reporters Without Borders exposed [Diana Panchenko as Russian propagandist](https://rsf.org/en/diana-panchenko-ukrainian-propagandist-working-kremlin)
 working for the Kremlin. <image:2557>

Fire crews battle the Kenneth Fire in the West Hills section of Los Angeles, California, Jan."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Voice of America (VOA) reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia exploited the Los Angeles wildfires to push anti-US and anti-Ukraine propaganda. The article mentions Maria Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, accusing the U.S. of hypocrisy regarding the use of inmate firefighters. The article also mentions that Lavrov claimed that the U.S. "burned almost all of California." <image:2557>

_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires from January 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Russia California wildfires assistance 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Tasnim News Agency reported on January 12, 2025, that Russia's Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on the California wildfires, mentioning reports of prisoners being mobilized to extinguish the fires. The article also noted that wildfires began spreading across Los Angeles County on January 7. ([https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)) <image:4830>, <image:4831>

The Dispatch reported on January 15, 2025, that Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, offered sanctuary to California fire victims who had not supported Ukraine since February 2022. ([https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/](https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/)) <image:4838> NPR reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia used the Los Angeles wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda. ([https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine)) <image:4849>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Russia commented on the California wildfires and that Vladimir Saldo offered sanctuary to fire victims. However, the evidence does not explicitly state that Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires.

The evidence suggests that Russia's involvement was more related to propaganda and offering sanctuary rather than direct assistance in extinguishing the fires.

To verify the claim, information is missing about whether Russia offered any form of assistance, such as personnel, equipment, or financial aid, to combat the wildfires.


## Actions
```
web_search("Russia offer assistance California wildfires")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
From [Source](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html): 
Content: Voice of America (VOA) reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia exploited the Los Angeles wildfires to push anti-US and anti-Ukraine propaganda. The article mentions Maria Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, accusing the U.S. of hypocrisy regarding the use of inmate firefighters. The article also mentions that Lavrov claimed that the U.S. "burned almost all of California." <image:2557>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The new evidence from Voice of America ([https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html)) reinforces the previous findings. It highlights Russia's exploitation of the California wildfires for propaganda purposes, including accusations of hypocrisy and claims that the U.S. "burned almost all of California."

The evidence continues to show no indication of Russia offering any assistance to combat the wildfires. Instead, the focus is on spreading anti-US and anti-Ukraine narratives.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of evidence supporting the offer of assistance.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires from January 2025."

The article also mentions that Lavrov claimed that the U.S. "burned almost all of California." <image:2557>

The evidence continues to show no indication of Russia offering any assistance to combat the wildfires. Instead, the focus is on spreading anti-US and anti-Ukraine narratives.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of evidence supporting the offer of assistance.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The fact-check reveals that Russia commented on the California wildfires in January 2025, with reports of propaganda and offers of sanctuary to fire victims. However, there is no evidence to support the claim that Russia offered assistance for the wildfires.

The decision option that best applies is `false`.

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires from January 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Russia California wildfires assistance 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Tasnim News Agency reported on January 12, 2025, that Russia's Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova commented on the California wildfires, mentioning reports of prisoners being mobilized to extinguish the fires. The article also noted that wildfires began spreading across Los Angeles County on January 7. ([https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case)) <image:4830>, <image:4831>

The Dispatch reported on January 15, 2025, that Vladimir Saldo, the governor of the Russian-occupied Kherson oblast region of Ukraine, offered sanctuary to California fire victims who had not supported Ukraine since February 2022. ([https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/](https://thedispatch.com/article/assessing-claims-that-russia-offered-sanctuary-to-california-fire-victims/)) <image:4838> NPR reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia used the Los Angeles wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda. ([https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/16/nx-s1-5259842/los-angeles-california-fires-russia-ukraine)) <image:4849>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Russia commented on the California wildfires and that Vladimir Saldo offered sanctuary to fire victims. However, the evidence does not explicitly state that Russia offered assistance for the California wildfires.

The evidence suggests that Russia's involvement was more related to propaganda and offering sanctuary rather than direct assistance in extinguishing the fires.

To verify the claim, information is missing about whether Russia offered any form of assistance, such as personnel, equipment, or financial aid, to combat the wildfires.


## Actions
```
web_search("Russia offer assistance California wildfires")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
From [Source](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html): 
Content: Voice of America (VOA) reported on January 16, 2025, that Russia exploited the Los Angeles wildfires to push anti-US and anti-Ukraine propaganda. The article mentions Maria Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, accusing the U.S. of hypocrisy regarding the use of inmate firefighters. The article also mentions that Lavrov claimed that the U.S. "burned almost all of California." <image:2557>


## Elaboration
The new evidence from Voice of America ([https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html)) reinforces the previous findings. It highlights Russia's exploitation of the California wildfires for propaganda purposes, including accusations of hypocrisy and claims that the U.S. "burned almost all of California."

The evidence continues to show no indication of Russia offering any assistance to combat the wildfires. Instead, the focus is on spreading anti-US and anti-Ukraine narratives.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of evidence supporting the offer of assistance.


## Final Judgement
The fact-check reveals that Russia commented on the California wildfires in January 2025, with reports of propaganda and offers of sanctuary to fire victims. However, there is no evidence to support the claim that Russia offered assistance for the wildfires.

The decision option that best applies is `false`.


## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The fact-check indicates that Russia commented on the California wildfires in January 2025, using the event for propaganda purposes, but there is no evidence to support the claim that Russia offered assistance for the wildfires. Sources like [Tasnim News Agency](https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/01/12/3236714/russia-notes-us-hypocrisy-in-california-fire-case) and [Voice of America](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-exploits-wildfires-in-los-angeles-to-push-anti-u-s-anti-ukraine-propaganda/7938909.html) highlight Russia's involvement in spreading anti-US and anti-Ukraine narratives related to the wildfires, rather than offering aid.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:21> This image shows an authentic Russian passport of deposed Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
reverse_search(<image:21>)
web_search("Bashar al-Assad Russian passport")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:21> This image shows an authentic Russian passport of deposed Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:21>)
web_search("Bashar al-Assad Russian passport")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Slavic_name): Found exact image on website with title: East Slavic name - Wikipedia
Content: "[Jump to content](#bodyContent)

[![Page semi-protected](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1b/Semi-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Semi-protection-shackle.svg.png)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#semi "This article is semi-protected until September 3, 2025 at 07:44 UTC.")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png)
